abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Structural Adjustment Credit in
            Guyana. In 1988, the Government of Guyana (GOG) launched
            comprehensive economic reforms under an Economic Recovery
            Program (ERP). An IDA's Structural Adjustment Credit
            (SAC) was part of the donor community's support for the
            ERP. The main objectives of the ERP were to (i) restore
            economic growth over the medium term; (ii) eliminate
            internal and external imbalances, (iii) incorporate the
            parallel economy into the official economy; and (iv)
            normalize Guyana's financial relations with external
            creditors. Overall performance of both IDA and the borrower
            is rated as satisfactory. Overall, these are important
            findings and lessons: a) commitments to thorough reforms
            emphasizing macro-economic stabilization and
            market-orientation can play a significant role in the
            economic turnaround; b) revenue enhancement is at least as
            important to restoring fiscal soundness as reductions in
            real expenditures and needs to be one of the earliest
            elements attended to in any adjustment program; c)
            Participants in the parallel economy who are generally
            averse to government regulations and taxation requirements
            will rejoin the official economy in response to a
            well-designed adjustment appropriately balancing the
            incentive and revenue considerations; d) tranche release
            conditions should be geared to successful implementation of
            major policy changes; e) it is important that in parallel to
            an adjustment program, an efficient and effective social
            impact alleviation program be put in place early, carefully
            identifying groups most likely to be affected; f) the
            ability of the public sector to implement effectively its
            development programs may be hampered by the sharp reductions
            in real wages in the public sector, which make it difficult
            to retain skilled technicians and managers, compromising the
            sustainability of otherwise promising institutions to reform
            and ; g) to ensure sustainability of a program involving
            debt reduction work-out, it is important that all important
            creditors be fully associated.
